post_text: OCDE’s Inside the Outdoors program will offer virtual field trips during the 2020–21 school year! See the post below for additional information and be sure to fill out the form if you’re interested in learning more.
shared_text:
Inside the Outdoors Foundation
August 19 at 11:05 PM ·

BEHIND THE SCENES: Just like you, we are spending our weeks preparing our "classrooms" and checking our wi-fi for the school year. We asked Program Naturalist, Kaitlyn, to snap a selfie while she was out exploring so we could get a peek into her location scouting trip.

Since we will be offering Virtual Field Trips this year, it's necessary to scout locations where we might normally have had in-person field trips to make sure they are appropriate for naturalist-guided virtual experiences. We're aiming for the same look and feel of a traditional Inside the Outdoors lesson.

While keeping learning continuity and distance learning goals in mind, all programs are designed by Orange County Department of Education STEM content experts and support current Next Generation Science Standards. Details and registration coming soon!

Sign up for our interest list here:
https://ocde.us/ito/Pages/Virtual-Programs.aspx

shared_text:
California Department of Education
June 6 at 4:49 PM ·

Reminder: State Superintendent Tony Thurmond will release the CDE guidance document, “Stronger Together: A Guidebook for the Safe Reopening of California’s Public Schools,” on Monday, June 8. During a news conference Monday at 11:15 a.m. on Facebook Live, Thurmond and CDE leaders will walk through the document’s key tools and recommendations.

This guidance will serve as a road map of recommendations for schools as they work with their local public health officials and school communities to navigate next steps. Educational leaders will find recommendations for face coverings, physical distancing, and symptom screening should schools plan to provide some form of in-person instruction and distance learning. The document will also provide in-depth considerations for designing high-quality and equitable instructional practices for all students.

post_text: The "why" behind social distancing.
shared_text:
Orange County Department of Education
March 17 at 7:51 PM ·

We’ve heard a lot about social distancing lately, and you might have also heard the term “flattening the curve.” The two concepts are connected.

The idea is that minimizing social contact can effectively slow the spread of a virus so you don’t get a huge wave of illnesses all at once. If that were to happen, a community might not have enough hospital beds or staff to manage patient care.

As explained in this brief video produced by OCDE’s Media Services, infectious disease experts say it helps to spread cases out over weeks or months so that health care systems can keep pace.
#flattenthecurve #COVID19 #staysafe

We’ve heard a lot about social distancing lately, and you might have also heard the term “flattening the curve.” The two concepts are connected.

The idea is that minimizing social contact can effectively slow the spread of a virus so you don’t get a huge wave of illnesses all at once. If that were to happen, a community might not have enough hospital beds or staff to manage patient care.

As explained in this brief video produced by OCDE’s Media Services, infectious disease experts say it helps to spread cases out over weeks or months so that health care systems can keep pace.
#flattenthecurve #COVID19 #staysafe

UPDATE: California public health officials announced late Wednesday night that large gatherings should be postponed or canceled across the state until at least the end of March.

Intended to slow the spread of #COVID-19, the updated policy from the state Department of Public Health says “non-essential” gatherings must be limited to no more than 250 people. Smaller events can proceed only if organizers can implement social distancing of 6 feet per person. Gatherings of individuals who are at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19 should be limited to no more than 10 people while also following social distancing guidelines.

As affirmed this morning by the Orange County Health Care Agency, the guidance does not apply to regular school classes, workplaces or other essential services.

You can also find the latest school-related COVID-19 updates at: www.newsroom.ocde.us
